p: All species of sea turtles exhibit an oviparous reproductive strategy that requires gravid females to return to their natal beaches to lay eggs. While eggs remain buried in the ground during the 45–65 day incubation period, they are exposed to an array of environmental variables that influence the development of eggs and hatchlings [ 1– 3]. During this time, developing embryos are also impacted by alterations to the nest environment induced by the eggs themselves [ 4, 5].
